body:
Took some benchmarks on this.

loop.rb:

```Ruby
10000.times do
  %w[test1 test2 test3 test4 test5].each do |test|
    test.chars.map(&:succ).join
  end
end
```

wet.rb:

```Ruby
10000.times do
  "test1".chars.map(&:succ).join
  "test2".chars.map(&:succ).join
  "test3".chars.map(&:succ).join
  "test4".chars.map(&:succ).join
  "test5".chars.map(&:succ).join
end
```

Results:

```
$ time ruby loop.rb

real	0m0.241s
user	0m0.232s
sys	0m0.003s

$ time ruby wet.rb

real	0m0.240s
user	0m0.226s
sys	0m0.006s
```

The repetitive one was always faster, but only marginally. Both fluctuated, but always came within a hundredth of a second of each other for 10 thousand runs of the loop. The difference in load time under normal use, one run of the loop, would be non-existent.

I think that the loop will help the code readability more than it hurts performance, but if there's still opposition to that I'll change it back.

**EDIT**: Haha. Just for shits and giggles (and out of a bit of curiosity) I did this [same thing in C](https://gist.github.com/aa6f7ebb676591ad7192), it consistently times at 0m0.003s real.
